author: barnabemonnot
content: hey! it's still here: https://github.com/barnabemonnot/abm1559/blob/master/nats-tx-bazooka.py I think it's a matter of deploying the library at a place where it can run continuously to generate transactions, but yes since the point of the testnet is more about block size and propagation it doesn't really matter where the transactions come from

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!376568077950910466> Is there any reason to believe that the issue is with the dual transaction pools and will just go away once we merge my latest PR and get rid of the dual-pools?

content:

<@!486501030046203915> Ok thanks. I will see if we can setup an AWS instance and deploy it.

author: abdel.stark
content: Oh i forgot that the signature is not handled by the script. Ok i will do some modification in the consumer to sign the transaction.

author: abdel.stark
content: Well, i am not sure the script is usable as is. I would wait until you can generate more evolved transactions simulating user behaviour. Because it is overkill to go through a message broker to generate transactions with hard coded parameters.

author: kubuxu
content:
<@!273808422753796097> 
We also use 2x slack.
> Do you happen to have stats for what percent of blocks are 100% full, and how often we have chains of 100% full blocks (or close to that) of different lengths?
You mean double full blocks, right. In that case for FIL it is a bit more complex as at each epoch our capacity is described by Poisson(5) so on average we have 5 blocks per epoch but we might have only 1. If it is only 1 block in an epoch it is almost guaranteed to be 200% full.

author: kubuxu
content: but I can try to pull some stats for you.
